text:
These files contain the first steps toward validation as xhtml11.
Suggestions:

1) most of the site-specifc stuff is one big blurb with many times repeating
   table cell features that do not validate correctly - how about adding some
   more layers of abstraction that group this - e.g. a menuTab macro or a 
   menuItem macro or a boxWithBottomRoundedCorners macro etc.?
2) If somebody really wants to remain compatible with html4 or earlier, a) a 
   html4func.vm needs to written in parallel to the xhtml11func.vm.
   b) Also, then it would be useful if some variable such as $htmlversion could 
   be configured in the build.xml/docs.xml and could be used in the .vsl and .vm
   files.

What do you think?

The effort is currently paused because I realized that I cannot use the VTL
inside the xml's to support my global "content constants" and multilinguality as
described in
http://issues.cocoondev.org/jira/secure/ViewIssue.jspa?key=FOR-18 . Any ideas
how to do this with anankia are highly appreciated!

creator: conor@apache.org
hauser@acm.org
text:
Congratulations for this achievement!

Your statement "I don't think we should bother adding the logo since we'll
sometimes slip out of compliance, I'm sure." surprises me in an open source context!
Is there anything wrong with slipping from time to time? 
Isn't the very nature of an open source effort like this one, that you - the
expert - need not to test exhaustively and that interested other parties (e.g.
me) will (randomly) take over that testing part and report a bug if incompliance
occurred? Isn't this "efficiency" the "secret sauce" of the open source movement?

As per your suggestion, the RFE has been posted in
http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=16329

creator: conor@apache.org
text:
Nothing wrong with slipping up time to time but IMHO, we should not advertise
something we are not guaranteed to be. 

In the end, I don't think the lack of the logo will prevent interested people
from validating the site and reporting problems as I am sure you yourself could
attest :-)

sure, but why not invite people to do it with placing the logo?
1) it encourages others to test their own site against it (leading by example?)
or would claim that is not a goal worthwhile to pursue?
2) it reduces the time to discovery in the case you do slip on your own site
because it facilitates to "not-yet-all-that" interested people to try that
feature too...   ;)
